Calculate a similarity matrix based on the Rips filtration

rips_similarity_matrix.Rd

Given input data, computes a Rips filtration and persistence diagram for each image. Then constructs a pairwise similarity matrix for each homology group (connected components and loops) based on the resulting persistence diagrams.

Usage

rips_similarity_matrix(images.df, max.threshold, print.progress = TRUE)

Arguments

images.df

A data.frame containing the image information. See details.

max.threshold

The maximum radius of the circles in the Rips filtration

print.progress

Boolean indicating whether progress in constructing the Rips filtrations across images should be printed.

Value

Returns a list of similarity (kernel) matrices and a list of the resulting persistence diagrams for each image.

Details

images.df should contain a PID column indicating which sample each image corresponds to. It should also contain columns x and y indicating the location of each cell. Each row in images.df corresponds to a cell within each image. See the package vignettes for an example of the structure.

To choose max.threshold, a reasonable first choice is to select the maximum possible radius that would cover all cells in each image. This could be the maximum width of the largest image, for example.

This function should be run as a first step of the TopKAT analysis. After that, the resulting kernel matrices may be fed into the TopKAT function.

Examples

# Construct a Rips filtration for each simulated image
simmat <- rips_similarity_matrix(data1.df, max.threshold = 100, print.progress = TRUE)
#> [1] "Rips diagram: 1"
